oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nashville in 1854, circa 1859
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A page from a mounted and bound volume of twenty-five pen-and-ink wash drawings, and two pen-and-ink maps of Nashville created by William A. Eichbaum during the 1850s. Eichbaum was a Nashville bookseller and resident for fifty years. The map on this page shows Nashville as it was in 1854. This detailed street map of the downtown area includes street names along with prominent buildings and their names. Boundaries consist of Lawrence Street (upper) and the Cumberland River (lower). Other prominent streets pictured include Demonbreun Street, McGavock Street, Broad Street, Spring Street, Union Street, Cedar Street, Gay Street, Line Street, McLemore Street, Spruce Street, Vine Street, High Street, Summer Street, Cherry Street, and College Street. Notable buildings include the jail, the courthouse, City Hall, the Capitol, First Methodist Church, Odd Fellows Hall, First Presbyterian Church, Old Christian Church, and Hume High School. Forms part of the William A. Eichbaum Sketchbook. 1 drawing : col. ; 5.75 x 9 in.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Eichbaum, William A., 1787-1873--Notebooks, sketchbooks, etc.
